seo.title: Parking in Positano: garages, street rules, and alternatives
seo.description: Where to park in Positano, what garages cost, when street spaces are realistic, and smarter car-free options.

linkLabel: Parking in Positano: where and costs
intro: Parking is scarce and pricey in Positano; reserve a garage early and treat the car as stored for your stay.

sections.title: Private garages in town
body: Mandara, Car Park Anna, and Di Gennaro take reservations—book 7–10 days ahead for July–August arrivals.
Rates hover around €35–€60 per 24 hours; confirm height limits (about 1.9 m / 6.2 ft) and whether you must leave keys with staff.

sections.title: Drop-off and payment routine
body: Use the short-stay lay-bys near Chiesa Nuova or Sponda to unload bags before parking; keep hazard lights on and move quickly.
Carry both card and cash—garages often accept cards but prefer cash for stays under 48 hours.

sections.title: Cheaper parking outside Positano
body: Covered lots in Meta, Piano di Sorrento, or Sorrento cost roughly €20–€25 per day and connect to Positano via SITA buses within 45 minutes.
Arriving from the north? Leave the car in Salerno’s port garages and sail over by ferry when seas are calm.

tips: Check ZTL/alternating plate notices before driving the SS163; fines are mailed internationally months later.
Pack a day bag with essentials before you hand over the keys—the garage may store cars bumper-to-bumper until checkout.

faqs.q: Can I park for just a few hours?
a: Garages charge hourly but switch to day rates quickly; for short errands use the 30-minute spaces near the Sponda bend.
Most run 07:00–00:00; warn attendants about late returns so they leave keys with the night porter.
